entry.title: Alice Creek Fire Reaches 5% Containment
entry.summary: AUGUSTA, MT – Firefighters saw the Alice Creek Fire grow an additional 437 acres yesterday, mostly along the northern flank in upper drainage of East Fork of Falls Creek (drains to Dearborn Canyon). In the late afternoon, on the west flank, fire spotted into Wildcat Gulch. National Guard helicopters are dropping water to cool the fire in active areas while a handcrew is working to keep the fire west of Alice Mountain Ridge. Red flag conditions will prevail through the weekend. These conditions are for critically dry, hot windy weather. Winds from the northwest with gusts up to 28 mph are expected in the late afternoon. This could cause the fire to become very active, producing visible columns of smoke. Due to these conditions, the burning period is lasting well into the early morning hours. entry.title: Sapphire Complex Daily Update 09.02.2017
entry.summary: Three fires comprise the Sapphire Complex: Little Hogback, Goat Creek, and Sliderock fires. Mike Almas’ Northern Rockies Type II Incident Management Team (IMT) is managing the incident. The fires are burning in steep, rocky terrain between the Rock Creek and Upper Willow Creek drainages. Little Hogback Fire: 31,322 acres, 30% contained. entry.title: Air Quality Smoke report, Libery Fire, Sept. 1, 2017
entry.summary: Smoke: Westerly flow will remain aloft behind yesterday’s frontal passage, which will create breezy afternoon and evening winds’ from the west. Active fire behavior is possible, especially in areas that have been blanketed in smoke the last several days. Yesterday, Rice Ridge, Liberty, and Alice Creek added 3,667 acres, 609 acres and 153 acres respectively. Fire: Westerly winds will continue to improve areas that have been blanketed by smoke, however the clear air will also allow more fire activity. Seeley Lake will continue to have Hazardous AQ in the morning followed by better AQ in the afternoon. Condon, Rainy Lake, Clearwater, and Lincoln maybe impacted by blowing smoke this afternoon and could be USG overall, while Arlee and Potomac should have moderate conditions today. Other: High pressure and poor smoke dispersion will return this weekend. Anticipate reduced roadway visibility (AM) especially if RH recovers to+70% (mid- elevation valleys). For additional information...

entry.title: Air Quality Report for 9-1-2017
entry.summary: Smoke: The hot, stagnant conditions from the last few days will give way to critical fire weather today for dry thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds. This will be followed by a dry cold front that should pass through the area beginning this evening bringing increased westerly winds. Active fire behavior, with the potential for rapid growth is possible. Yesterday, Rice Ridge and Liberty added 1,560 acres and 529 acres respectively. As the cold front moves through this evening and tomorrow, accumulated smoke should start to clear but this could be followed by new smoke. entry.title: Sapphire Complex Daily Update 09.01.2017
entry.summary: Three fires comprise the Sapphire Complex: Little Hogback, Goat Creek, and Sliderock fires. Mike Almas’ Northern Rockies Type II Incident Management Team (IMT) is managing the incident. The fires are burning in steep, rocky terrain between the Rock Creek and Upper Willow Creek drainages. Little Hogback Fire: 30,929 acres, 30% contained. Thursday, the fire continued to back downhill along the southwestern flank between upper Sheep Gulch and Capron Creek, and helicopters helped moderate fire behavior with water drops. Thunderstorms and associated wind moved much of the smoke out of the area, which could result in more active fire behavior. At this point, fire managers believe burnout operations in Capron Creek may be the only way to secure firelines in that area, but gusty winds prevented those plans for a second day in a row. entry.title: National Guard Boeing CH-47 Chinook helicopters arrive on Alice Creek Fire
entry.summary: A COMMUNITY MEETING WILL BE HELD AT THE WOLF CREEK ELEMENTARY SCHOOL, TONIGHT AT 6 P.M. ALL ARE WELCOME TO ATTEND. AUGUSTA, MT – Two National Guard Boeing CH-47 Chinook helicopters arrived Thursday afternoon to provide air support to firefighters on the Alice Creek Fire. These very fast helicopters are able to carry up to 2,000 gallons of water per load and can fly for two-and- a-half hours before needing to refuel. Throughout the duration of this fire, firefighters have relied heavily on helicopters to drop water to cool the fire. With their massive water capacity, these helicopters are a welcome asset. These very large helicopters may catch the eye of drivers along Hwy. 200. Please do not stop along the roadway to look at the aircraft dipping as it may be dangerous to other drivers. entry.title: SPERRY CHALET WAS LOST AND FIREFIGHTERS ARE SAFE
entry.summary: Thursday afternoon at approximately 6:00 pm, the main building at the Sperry Chalet was lost to the Sprague Fire. A highly skilled group of firefighters were staged at the Sperry Chalet over the last week. Those firefighters had an extensive hose lay, sprinkler, and pump system installed to protect all of the structures associated with the Chalet. The high winds experienced Thursday afternoon pushed the fire to the north and east. The firefighters were supported by 4 helicopters and made a valiant stand to save the structure. They were unsuccessful in saving the main Sperry Chalet. The firefighters remain on site, ARE SAFE, and are actively engaged in protecting the remaining structures. The Sprague Fire perimeter is now estimated at 4,646 acres after a second Red Flag Warning day. entry.title: Horseback Rides and Boat Tours to Continue at Lake McDonald
entry.summary: Swan Mountain Outfitters will continue to guide horseback rides out of their Lake McDonald corral, and Glacier Boat Company will continue to offer boat tours on Lake McDonald, with some schedule changes to accommodate concerns about localized poor air quality during mornings and evenings.Horseback rides will be offered with a shortened schedule, with no ride being offered at 7:45 am. Visitors can call Swan Mountain Outfitters at 406-387-4405 for reservation inquiries or changes.Boat tours at Lake McDonald will no longer be offered at 11:00 am and 7:00 pm. Ticket office hours will be 12:00 pm to 6:30 pm. Boat rental hours at Lake McDonald will be offered from 12:00 pm to 5:30 pm. For questions and reservations, contact Glacier Park Boat Company at 406-257-2426.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning Remains in Effect Today
entry.summary: POLSON, Mont. – The National Weather Service has issued a Red Flag Warning for western Montana in effect from 1 p.m. until 9 p.m. High temperatures, winds gusting to 30 miles per hour and low relative humidities are expected. Four lightning strikes hit the Flathead Reservation yesterday and more lightning is possible today. Red Flag Warnings indicate there is high potential for fire combustion, and for any new or existing fires to spread rapidly. During this period of critical fire weather, firefighters will continue to secure and hold firelines on the Blue Bay Fire, as well as monitor unburned areas outside of containment lines for spot fires. Acreage remains steady at 490 acres but containment has increased to 80 percent. With the increased potential for rapid fire spread, some resources on the Blue Bay Fire have been identified for initial attack. entry.summary: Three fires comprise the Sapphire Complex: Little Hogback, Goat Creek, and Sliderock fires. Mike Almas’ Northern Rockies Type II Incident Management Team (IMT) is managing the incident. The fires are burning in steep, rocky terrain between the Rock Creek and Upper Willow Creek drainages. Fire managers will hold a public meeting jointly for both the Sapphire Complex and the Meyers Fire TONIGHT at 5:30 p.m. at the Granite County High School library. Little Hogback Fire: 30,929 acres, 30% contained. entry.title: Another Red Flag Warning in Effect for the Sprague Fire Area
entry.summary: A red flag warning is in effect today. With low relative humidity and breezy winds, another critical fire weather day is expected Thursday. With the red flag warning and the steep, rugged terrain that makes up much of the area, fire managers are focusing on firefighter safety as the number one priority. Fire managers will continue to concentrate on structure protection and fuels reduction around park service facilities. The Sprague Fire perimeter is now estimated at 2,097 acres. An infrared flight on Tuesday night reported a growth of 522 acres primarily on the southwest flank. Firefighters continue to reduce fuels around structures and utilize helicopter bucket drops as needed, particularly in the Snyder Creek and Sperry Chalet areas. The fire did cross Snyder Creek on the northeast tip last evening. entry.summary: The Bitterroot National Forest has an Emergency Fire Closure in place due to the Nelson Creek Fire on the West Fork Ranger District.
